binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Do not use this term as it is used purely as a way of grouping textile technique terms.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Term used to describe a common class of pottery produced in southern Iraq and south-west Iran during the early Islamic period but continuing a much longer local tradition. Typically coloured with copper oxides to produce green, blue or turquoise glaze on a pale yellow body but as the glaze is unstable it often weathers heavily.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term is a sub-variety of intaglio printmaking in which tone is created by etching around grains on resin.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal:
For Middle East this term is used to describe low temperature heating or accidental baking. It is distinct from firing (see 'fired').
The only exception is where this technique is used to describe the conservation treatment of cuneiform tablets which were previously unbaked (see Material 'clay').

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Used to describe plastic effects on the surface of a pottery vessel resulting from the manipulation of a slip. The Department of Greece and Rome also use the term as a ware, when the technique is found on Minoan Pottery

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Technique for preserving skins, involving submersion to leach fat, used North America.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term 'enamel' should be entered as a Material.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term is a mixed variety of printmaking, patented by George Baxter in 1935, using multiple wood-engraved blocks printed in colour over an intaglio key-plate.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Beads when strung upon a set of interconnected elements to form a panel or network.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Japanese woodblock print with hand-coloured pink pigment.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Early Japanese woodblock prints generally with two printed colours, pink (beni) and green, but also yellow, indigo and brown.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Enter ZINC ALLOY and SILVER in the Materials field.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Used for impressing design on e.g. birchbark in North America.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is restricted to intentional bleaching of textiles, cloths, skins, etc.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Use for textiles, etc.; for prints, use alternative terms. Prehistory & Europe: use TRANSFER-PRINTED for tiles.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term is a variety of photographic process, in which a drawing on transparent paper is printed down onto paper prepared with iron salts which turn blue under the action of light.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term braided has been used in both a textile and non-textile context.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Enter BRASS in the Material field.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The cabochon cut gives a facetless, domed form.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal:
The term 'champlevé' is used in two contexts: enamelling and in ceramics. This second use of the term is referred to by 'champlevé' (pottery).
For the simple term 'champlevé', the term 'enamel' should be entered as a Material.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term 'champlevé' is used in two contexts: enamelling and in ceramics. This second use of the term is referred to by 'champlevé' (pottery).

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Potter's term used to described the effect whereby a tool such as a wooden rib is held against the gently rotating pot to create a series of shallow vertical undulations on the body of the pot.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Occurs on lacquer; the outline of a design is cut with thin lines and these are filled or partially filled with metal dust (usually gold or silver).

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: A carving technique also adapted to metal-casting to give metal surfaces a chiselled effect by use of a carved mould.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Method developed by Arent Lauri Christensen which employs oil varnish with sand or marble dust on aluminium or plastic plate to create the printing surface.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Enter CHROMIUM in the Material field.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a variety of colour lithograph using multiple plates which are stippled to achieve the effect of continuous rather than flat tone.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal:
The term 'cloisonné' is used in two contexts: enamelling and for the setting of garnets and other stones in cloisons on metalwork. This second use of the term is referred to by cloisonné (inlay).
For the enamelling 'cloisonné', 'enamel' should be entered as a Material.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term 'cloisonné' is used in two contexts: enamelling and for the setting of garnets and other stones in cloisons on metalwork. This second use of the term is referred to by cloisonné (inlay).

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Painting on ceramics which has not been fired.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to a technique in the manufacture of glass objects.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is for a print made from an inked printing surface that has had elements (usually odd-shaped pieces of metal) or objects fused to it

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a variety of photomechanical process that prints using a process akin to lithography from a surface of light-hardened gelatine.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal:
This term is restricted to prints and covers all varieties of prints on which the colour has been printed rather than added by hand to the sheet after it has been printed. It includes both printing from multiple plates and from a single plate coloured 'à la poupée'. The term hand-coloured should be used for prints where the colouring has been added by hand after printing. The term 'colour' should be entered in addition to a print technique in cases where more than one block, plate, stone or screen has been used. N.B. Lithographs solely using the tint-stone for background colour do not qualify as 'colour lithographs'.
See also 'woodblock' for Japanese colour sheet prints, which after 1765 are invariably colour woodblock printed.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Use for colour photographs when the precise type of colour photographic process is not known.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Comb-washed applies to where a thick wash or slip has been applied to the surface, in which a reserve pattern is created by combing with some form of multiple-toothed tool to form often complex straight and /or wavy patterns.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term should be used for contemporary works combining several techniques, such as printmaking, drawing, collage, etc. See also the Technique mixed media for the specific printmaking technique, used in Victorian prints.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term is restricted to the Stein Project.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is mainly used to cover all types of modern printmaking where the image has been generated from a computer rather than by hand; such prints will almost always be laser printed (q.v). For such objects, 'print' should be entered in Object Name and the printing method should be entered in the Description.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Enter COPPER in the Material field.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal:
The term refers to the coating of an object in copper by any uncertain process. Enter COPPER in the Material field.
See also the term 'copper-plated'.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Couching is achieved by holding a cord, braid or a variety of different threads in place with a stitch.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term is restricted to Chinese Stein textiles.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to a form of decoration on Medieval tiles where the design is stamped or impressed into the clay. See also the terms 'impressed' and 'stamped'.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Technique by which the rim of a blown glass vesse is created. By using the point of a diamond (or similar sharp stone) and a train of soft glass, the vessel is separated from the 'overblow'. This method is most frequently used in the making of thin-walled vessels, often those which have been blown into moulds (Tait 1991).

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a variety of intaglio printmaking that uses specially-designed tools to build on the copper a facsimile of a crayon drawing; such prints are often printed in coloured inks.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: A technique applied in the 19thC to colour woodblock prints (Asia).

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: a mode of decoration on Seville tiles by which the outlines of a design were impressed to keep the coloured glazes from intermingling (Honey).

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: a pottery technique by which the outlines of a design, drawn with manganese and grease, served to keep the coloured glazes from intermingling (Honey).

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to a technique applied to metal objects; generally inlaid, but can also refer to etched steel.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term is restricted to the Stein Project.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to impressed decoration on metal made with a die.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Japanese for 'copperplate print'. The technology was first used in Japan in the late 18thC.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term is restricted to the Stein Project.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Doucai (鬥彩 ‘joined or interlocking colours’), is a decorative technique in which porcelain painters outlined or half-outlined designs in blue pigment directly on to the biscuit (leather-hard porcelain body). Then they glazed and fired the generally small and delicate cups, bowls and dishes. Next they filled in and added the outlined designs over the glaze with yellow, red, green and aubergine enamel colours and refired them in a muffle kiln at a lower temperature. Potters first used this particular twice-fired technique in the early-fifteenth century but perfected it in the Chenghua era.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a generic term used in the BM to cover all methods of hand-drawing on paper in the Western tradition; it includes watercolour, pen and ink, and graphite. The term 'painted' is used for finished works on paper in the Asiatic schools.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal:
Drawn glass beads are made by blowing a bubble into the molten gather or pushing a rod or other tool into the gather, attaching a rod to the opposite end of the gather and gradually pulling into a long continuous tube. This process is exhausting and involves several individuals over the course of several hours. The bubble forms the hollow centre and the tube is cut into lengths of about a metre which are then assigned to other workers who chop the tubes into small individual beads. The beads are usually heat-treated in order to finish the sharp ends: this is done by packing them in ash or sand to minimise them sticking together when they are re-heated and stirring them until the ends become smooth and rounded. They are then cleaned, sorted by size where necessary and in recent times were threaded for sale according to the weight of the bunch.
This term has only been used in a small proportion of the bead records.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a variety of intaglio printmaking in which the plate is directly scored with a sharp needle; it is often combined with etching on a single plate.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The action of forming a tile from dust clay in a press which compacted the clay between two dies. (Austwick 1980).

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Darkening wood to create the appearance of ebony.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal:
The term refers to the production of metal copies of an original by an electrochemical process (generally referred to as electroforming), a basic plating process (mainly copper) aided by an electrical source, in which metal ions migrate from an anode and are 'deposited' onto the surface of a mould (cathode) gradually building to take the form and detail of the original.
The term 'electrotype' is entered as an Object Name, as well as the Object Name of the original. See Object Name 'electrotype' for a definition of that term and its use in the British Museum records.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term refers to the deposition of a layer of metal by electrolysis; if known to be silver enter SILVER to the Material field, otherwise enter METAL (or a more appropriate NT).

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to the process patented under the name ‘xerography’, and other forms of copying using electrically charged particles.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term should not be used for the print technique referred to as EMBOSSING.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term is a printmaking method in which a design is impressed into paper without the use of any ink.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal:
This term is only used in the context of metalwork, and the Material 'enamel' is entered for such records.
- The only exception is for European Iron Age material, where the Technique 'enamelled' is entered, but not the Material 'enamel' (See the Scope Note for the Material term 'enamel').
- If the object is simply a sample of enamel, the Technique 'enamelled' is not entered.
N.B.
The term 'enamelled' is not used in the context of ceramics, where the object is described as, e.g.: 'painted in enamels', or 'decorated in enamels' (with the resulting Techniques 'glazed' and painted') and no entry 'enamel' in Material'.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The technique refers to the engraving of patterns upon metals by machinery. (OED)

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal:
This term is used to cover directly incised surfaces.
In the context of Early Medieval material, the term refers to decoration, lettering, deliberate marks and signs, etc. cut into the surface of an object, generally to some depth and width. It also refers to incising designs in metal, wood, etc. for reproduction by printing.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a printmaking method, a variety of intaglio printmaking, in which the lines on a metal plate are cut using a v-shaped tool called a burin.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Use for three-dimensional objects only. For prints, use ETCHING.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a printmaking method, a variety of intaglio printmaking, in which the lines are bitten by acid into a metal plate.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term is used in the context of glass bead production. It has only been entered in a small proportion of the bead records.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Feldspar is a name given to a group of minerals, usually white or flesh-red in colour, occurring in crystals or in crystalline masses. They consist of a silicate of alumina with soda, potash, lime, etc.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Only use the term when the technique is of significance.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: For Middle East this term is used to describe the deliberate hardening of clay or composite materials through heating in a kiln. It is distinct from baking which is at a lower temperature or accidental (see 'baked').

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: refers to stone fractured to give a sharp edge.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Technique whereby glass of one colour is fused onto the outer surface of glass of a different colour, by taking a gather of the inner colour - sometimes partly inflated - and dipping it into a crucible containing molten glass od the outer colour. By repeating the procedure, a multicoloured layered glass can be produced (Tait 1991).

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Only use the term if it the technique was used in the manufacture of the object.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal:
The term refers to a technique for making beads which involved heating one or more small flat pieces of glass, bending them over a piece of wire and gently heating the junction(s) to fuse the edges: they may be recognised by this seam-like junction which runs parallel with the perforation. They are typically made from one piece of glass and therefore have a single seam (hence known as single-strip folded beads) but others are made by fusing two pieces of glass and therefore have two seams (double-strip folded beads). This is likely to be a very old tradition within the Middle East and is related to winding.
This term has only been used in a small proportion of the bead records.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal:
Starched, folded rectangles of silk, sewn together to form geometric flower- and gem- like designs.
This decorative technique is found on many Miao (Hmong) textiles.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Only use the term when it refers to a process in the manufacture of the object.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal:
[Blind-printing] Design impressed without the use of ink, to create textural effects; used primarily for East Asian prints.
NT gauffrage

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Enter GESSO in the Materials field.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal:
The term 'gilded' refers to an overlay (wholly or in parts) of a thin layer of gold. The term 'gold' is entered in the Materials field as well as terms for the base Materials.
'Silver-gilt' refers to a silver base to which a layer of gilding has been applied, and the Technique entered is 'gilded', the Materials 'silver' and 'gold'.
See also the term 'gold-plated'.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: There are instances where objects which are decorated with underglaze are not glazed, but they are uncommon.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Only use the term when it refers to a process in the manufacture of the object.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a method (patented in 1842) of creating a relief printing block by drawing through a compostion on a metal plate, and making an electrotype of the result.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal:
Enter GOLD in the Material field.
See also the term 'gilded'.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The technique of roughening the internal or external surface of a pot by applying sand before firing.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: A form of carved lacquer where alternate layers of different- coloured lacquers are carved in schematised spiral scrolls. The deeply cut lines are often bevelled. (Rawson 1992).

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a method (patented in 1837) of creating a relief printing block by drawing through a block of plaster mounted on a metal base, and making an elctrotype of the result.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term is restricted to prints where the colouring has been added by hand after printing. The term 'colour' should be used when the work has been printed in coloured inks.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Use only for ceramic objects which are not wheel-made. For the Middle East Department the details of how a pot was hand-made (e.g. slabbed, coiled, etc.) will be entered in the Description field. This term can be used in conjunction with WHEEL-FINISHED, for example to describe a coiled pot finished on a tournette.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Technique, introduced in the Kamakura period, where sprinkled powders are applied directly on a smooth lacquered surface in very low relief so that only the thickness of the final protective lacquer coating is raised above the surface. (Dictionary of Japanese Architectural and Art Historical Terminology, JAANUS)

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to relief decoration made of lacquer putty (thayo) and set with glass spangles.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: In the context of Early Medieval material, the term refers to decoration, lettering, deliberate marks, etc. cut into the surface of an object, generally fairly lightly and not very deeply.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is used for engraving on seals and gems; not for printmaking.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal:
This term is used for the class of printmaking using metal plates inked so as to print from the incisions (lines or dots) rather than the surface. Use whenever possible a more specific term. Only use this term when the method is unclear or when numerous varieties of method are used on a single plate.
For three-dimensional objects use INTAGLIO.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Japanese woodblock print employing white lines on a black background in imitation of stone rubbings.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to warp faced compound plain weave.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to warp faced compound twill.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term is restricted to the slip decoration technique.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to a technique of painting and dyeing on cloth using a distinctive pen.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Decorative technique for metalwork where design is carved with single strokes of a square chisel held at an angle.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to an Indian textile technique whereby gold spangled decoration is applied with glue to cloth.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Japanese name for the gold color added to Chinese 'wucai' porcelain, featuring a white-base with red, green and yellow motifs, made in Ming-dynasty China. (Dictionary of Japanese Architectural and Art Historical Terminology, JAANUS)

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Decorative technique on Japanese paintings and lacquer objects of applied strips of cut gold leaf.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to the technique of putting gold and silver onto steel arms and armour (a type of overlay).

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal:
For the Asian collections, objects described as 'lacquer' imply the technique of lacquer application on a substrate, and should have Technique 'lacquered'. Enter the Material 'lacquer (ie. tree resin)' or 'lac' (ie. insect secretion), depending on circumstance. Many objects from South Asia with 'lacquer' in Material may in fact be lacquered using lac.
See also LACQUERED in the Techniques field.
As a general rule, lacquered objects from the Middle East and South Asia are made using 'lac', while those from South East Asia and the far East are made using 'lacquer'.
See also LACQUER and LAC in the Materials field.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Enter GOLD in the Material field. Not all records with references to 'gold leaf' have 'leaf-gilded' as a Technique. See also the Materials thesaurus.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to compound twill weft faced on both sides.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to a stamped linear design on a Medieval tile.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a relief printmaking process similar to woodcut, but using a sheet of linoleum in place of wooden block.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a planographic printmaking process, using a stone or metal surface. It relies on the antipathy of grease and water to enable a drawn design to be used to make a print from.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Beadwork or quillwork woven in a strip on a bow loom made from withe or stick.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term is used in the context of string-work, e.g. for string bags.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: A method of casting which involves making a wax model, sometimes with a core of another substance, enclosing the model in a mould, melting away the wax, and pouring molten metal or glass into the void resulting from the removal of the wax, then allowing the material to harden to harden before removing the mould. The final stage after casting usually entails polishing of the finished object.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is for use with three-dimensional objects

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term generally refers to green-hard handles, spouts, knobs, etc., being stuck on using a little slip as adhesive, as opposed to those applied and smoothed. This distinction is not always adhered to.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Japanese decorative technique of metal dust sprinkled onto lacquer before it is set, and sometimes repeated in layers.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Applied to a shaping process of glass manufacture in which molten glass is rolled smooth on a polished surface.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a printmaking method invented in 1831 that reproduces in two dimensions the design on a coin or medal by using a tracing machine.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a relief printmaking method, printing from the surface of a metal plate; used in XVc often decorating the surface of the plate with punched holes (hence the term manière criblée - sieved manner')

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is an intaglio printmaking process which works from dark to light by smoothing down with a burnisher the surface of a roughened metal plate.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Surface treatment used on Romano-British and Iron Age pottery.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: A term used to describe the technology whereby objects are embedded with thinly sliced sections of glass canes of multicoloured chevron, floral or other patterns in alternating concentric bands (Tait 1991).

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal:
The term refers to enamelled work on metal in Iran and North India (associated especially with Jaipur in Rajasthan). The term 'enamel' should be entered in the Materials field.
.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal:
The term refers to printmaking resulting from a single plates incorporating various intaglio techniques, a process used for Victorian prints.
Double-key with the individual print techniques if known.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to modelling by hand, and should not be used for objects which happen to be models, unless the technique is specifically referred to. NB. MODELLED, MOULD-MADE and MOULDED have been used interchangeably in some cases.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a type of drawing in which printing ink is transferred to the paper from another surface. This can be done drectly, by offsetting a composition from a glass or metal plate, or indirectly by tracing through from one sheet to another via a sheet of carbon paper or similar. Monotypes are classified as prints rather than drawings.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The Middle East Department use MOULD-MADE in preference to MODELLED, MOULDED, etc. However in other departments, MODELLED, MOULD-MADE and MOULDED have been used interchangeably in some cases.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: If the object is MOULD-MADE, use that term instead. For Prehistory & Europe, see MOULDING in the Form field. NB. The terms MOULD-MADE, MODELLED AND MOULDED have been used interchangeably in some cases.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Only use the term when the technique is of significance.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Pattern of small dots (thought to resemble fish-roe) beaten out with an indented chisel, usually used as a background pattern on metal fittings (kanagu). (Dictionary of Japanese Architectural and Art Historical Terminology, JAANUS)

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Literally, 'pear-skin ground'; name given to two widely-used techniques invented in the Kamakura period. In one, large irregular shaped gold flakes are scattered at differing angles in many layers in wet 'nashiji urushi', a highly translucent lacquer that has been tinted orange; a further coating is applied and polishing exposes the flakes to produce an uneven surface texture. This technique is often used to give a uniformly decorative surface to large but less important areas, such as the interior of drawers or the underside of boxes. In the other, a fine metallic powder is sprinkled onto a lacquered surface; when dry, a coat of transparent lacquer is applied and lightly polished. (Dictionary of Japanese Architectural and Art Historical Terminology, JAANUS)

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Enter NICKEL in the Material field.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Enter NIELLO in the Materials field.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Japanese full colour woodblock prints, first perfected in Edo in 1764-1765.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a variety of chromolithograph which is treated with a layer of varnish to give the effect of an oil painting.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is used for the direct biting by acid of localised areas of a plate, when no design has previously been fixed to the plate.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: A form of open-work in which holes are pierced in sheet-metal with a chisel to produce a design.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Only use the term when the process was intentional, rather than accidental.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal:
A term that covers all types of painting in oils and fresco, and also finished works on paper of the schools of Asia. For Western traditions of art, the word 'drawn' has been used for works on paper, including watercolours.
N.B.
The term is also used in the context of ceramics, where the object is described as, e.g.: 'painted in overglaze enamels', or 'decorated in overglaze enamels' (with the resulting Techniques 'glazed' and painted' and Material 'enamel').
For ceramics in the Greek and Roman Department, the term painted is also to be used in the sense of ‘decorated’. The composition of the ‘paint’, which can often be described as a ‘slip’ is irrelevant. Thus the term 'slip-painted' is not used for ceramics in that Department, and 'slipped' or 'painted' are used instead.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Enter GOLD in the Material field.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term refers to a rare type of XVc object related to a woodcut, in which a layer of paste was spread on a sheet of paper and covered with a sheet of tin foil. The design was printed on top of the foil in ink from a woodcut so that the foil presented a glittering background (now usually degraded).

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: A form of decoration in which a relief pattern is built up by repeated applications of thin white slip. (Austwick 1980).

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a general term used to cover all types of photograph. Whenever possible use one of the narrower terms of photography.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a photomechanical process of printmaking, in which a photographic image is transferred to a metal plate that is then printed in intaglio (qv)

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a photomechanical process of printmaking, in which a photographic image is transferred to a stone or metal surface that is then printed lithographically

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a general term used to cover all types of printmaking based on photographic images. Whenever possible use one of the narrower terms

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a photomechanical process of printmaking, in which a photographic image is transferred to a metal surface that is then printed in relief. These prints may be line-blocks or half-tones (rephotographed through a screen). This was the standard method of illustrating books in the era of letterpress.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: A technique of either casting or blowing glass into a specially formed mould to create ribbed "pillars" round the sides of a vessel.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The technique of shaping soft glass by manipulating it with pincers. It is used for making entirely functional - or perhaps structural - elements of an object, and also for purely decorative ones (Tait 1991).

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term is used for glass and metal, as well as pottery.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: A system of decoration using specially made pins on watch cases and boxes which usually have a covering of turtle-shell (tortoise-shell), leather or fish skin (shagreen). As well as acting as a decorative element, the pins also serve to fixing the covering on the metal carcass of the case. The pins are generally arranged in floral patterns, but can also take the form of coronets, animals and birds. In more sophisticated examples pictorial representations are made up using pins and larger engraved pieces of metal and wires inlaid into the surface - a technique known as piqué posé.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a general term used to cover the processes of printmaking (basically the lithographic group) that print from the surface rather than in relief or intaglio.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Plating is a term generally used for any of the methods of applying a surface layer of another metal onto a metal substrate, including those used in Antiquity.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term 'enamel' should be entered as a Material.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Flaking technique used in the knapping of flint.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is used to cover all methods of printing onto paper or other flat surfaces where the precise technique was not clear when writing the catalogue entry

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a method of decorating surfaces with a pointed tool.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Used to describe technique of blackening without engraving.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: technique whereby incised lines are filled with gold; only on lacquer.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Term used to describe glass-blowing technique where the vessel is re-inflated after dipping into a patterned mould.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a variety of relief printmaking, where instead of being cut away with the knife, the background is eaten away by acid,

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a general term to cover all varieties of relief printmaking. Whenever possible use one of the narrower terms.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: To be narrow term of smoked

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term is used for flint and stone objects.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The creation of a series of ridges by incising to create relief.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Flaking technique used in the knapping of flint.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Only use the term when the technique is of special significance.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term applies to the technique of incising a line with a twisting action to produce a zigzag effect.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to a glass-making technique.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a method of decorating surfaces.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a methof of recording a carved design in low relief by rubbing over a sheet of paper placed on top with a soft pencil, crayon or chalk

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to weft faced compound twill. The term is restricted to the Stein Project.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Use when a pottery vessel is rolled in sand to make a decorative surface

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to a technique whereby decoration is introduced between two layers of glass (Tait 1991).

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Satin is a weave structure and so is included, like 'velvet', in the Techniques rather than Materials thesaurus. Both terms, however, are commonly used to describe what an object is made of (or a support). Although in the case of satin, the lustrous effect is often made using silk thread, other fibres can also be used.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to weft faced compound satin.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Only enter the term when the technique was used in the manufacture of the object.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a method of printmaking using a fine mesh through which the ink is forced onto paper. A design may be attached to the mesh by a stencil, or by stopping-out manually or via a photographic process (hence the term photoscreenprint, which is not here distinguished from other methods of screenprinting).

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal:
For objects that have been deliberately impressed with a seal.
The term 'seal-impression' should be entered in Object Name.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Finely textured surfaces that appear to be slipped with the same material that constitutes the clay body, distinct slip is difficult to determine and could have resulted from wiping the surfaces with a wet hand.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: A technique of decorating pottery in which a layer of slip is scored through to reveal the contrasting ground underneath (see Hodges).

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Decorative technique of sunken relief carving.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to a technique of laying gold leaf on lacquered surface.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal:
Enter SILVER in the Material field.
See also the term 'silvered'.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal:
The term refers to the coating of an object in silver by any uncertain process. Add SILVER to the Material field. See also SILVER-LEAF in Materials.
See also the term 'silver-plated'.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to the technique of applying slip with a comb.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to the technique of applying slip with a feather.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal:
Slip-painted is a term typically used where a coloured slip has been applied to create decoration.
The term 'slip-painted' is not used for ceramics in the Greek and Roman Department, where the term 'slipped’ is used when the object is slipped but otherwise undecorated, and the term ‘painted’ is used in the sense of ‘decorated’. The term ‘slip-painted’ is avoided in this context to avoid confusion between 'painted' and 'slipped' because what is usually referred to as ‘paint’ could be described as a ‘slip’ in terms of composition, or vice versa.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal:
Slipped applies to where the surface has been covered (either dipped or block covered) with a fine clay ('slip') to give it extra fineness of appearance or to change its colour, particularly if then covered with a transparent glaze and then incised (sgraffiato technique).
Slip-painted is a term typically used where a coloured slip has been applied to create decoration but this term is not used for ceramics in the Greek and Roman Department, where the term 'slipped’ is used when the object is slipped but otherwise undecorated, and the term ‘painted’ is used in the sense of ‘decorated’. The term ‘slip-painted’ should be avoided in this context to avoid confusion between 'painted' and 'slipped' because what is usually referred to as ‘paint’ could be described as a ‘slip’ in terms of composition, or vice versa.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The process of heating glass until gravity forces it to conform to the shape of the form (heat-resistant object used to create the final shape) on which it rests (Tait 1991).

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a method of printmaking in which a drawing is made on a sheet of paper on a soft etching ground, pulled off, and the resulting design transferred to the plate by etching

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: A technique generally applied to glassware.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term is restricted to metalwork. See also SPUN.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: A term widely used in literature on pottery techniques. It refers to coloured pigment applied under a glaze which has run and dispersed during the firing. This term does not apply to unglazed pots from Ancient Egypt, which have occasionally also been described as 'splashed', but which have been quite literally splashed with colour, probably by shaking it off a reed brush.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to a form of warp manipulation that can be either interlinked, interlaced or intertwined.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term is restricted to textiles. See also SPINNING.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is used for stamping used to decorate surfaces of objects, not for printmaking. See also 'impressed' and, for tiles, 'counter-relief'.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a simple method of printmaking, using pigment brushed through stencils onto paper to create the design. For Prints & Drawings, use the term for early stencil colouring, for modern pochoir processes and for monochrome roneo prints.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a method of decorating surfaces. Do not use this term for prints - see STENCIL.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a variety of intaglio printmaking in which the tone is created by making numerous dots on the plate, either directly or via etching.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a method of decorating surfaces. For prints, use STIPPLE.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term should not be entered for coins, as it is assumed. If a coin is cast, enter 'cast' in Description and Technique.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to the application of stucco to a substrate, e.g. wood. The term stucco is entered as a material as well as the substrate term.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Early Japanese monochrome woodblock print in sumi (ink).

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: A structural weaving term unique to the Andes.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: A structural weaving term unique to the Andes.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Japanese decorative technique, developed in the Muromachi period, where metallic powders are applied to soft surface designs built up through a mixture of lacquer and charcoal or clay dust. They are affixed by a protective lacquer coat and polished. (Dictionary of Japanese Architectural and Art Historical Terminology, JAANUS)

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Japanese woodblock prints hand-coloured with an orange-red pigment, produced from the late 17th century to the first quarter of the 18th century. (Encyclopedia Britannica)

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Kesi means silk tapestry and is not a technique as such, but refers to the finished product.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to weft faced compound tabby.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to a technique used to produce a specific type of meshwork lace made by looping and knotting a length of thread using a small shuttle.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal:
This term is a method of painting using egg-yolk as the binding medium for the pigment.
(See Thompson, D V, (tr.) 1960. Cennino d'Andrea Cennini's The Craftsman's Handbook (Il libro dell'arte) 2nd edn. New York: Dover.)

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term refers to a technique in metalwork as well as ceramics (for which there are several NTs). Use the Materials field to narrow any searches.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Indigenous Australians used termites to hollow out didjeridus.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal:
In modern manufacturing, tin-plating is usually the application of a thin layer of tin by electro-plating onto iron to make things like tin cans, (and the same method is also used for silver-plating and gold-plating). The term 'tin' should be entered as a Material.
See also the term 'tinned'.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal:
Tinned (or tinning) refers to a technique in which a thin layer of tin is applied to an otherwise non-tin item to give it an impression of being made of silver. Another use is to coat the inside of copper vessels to prevent poisoning by copper salts.
The term 'tin' is entyered as an additional Material. See also the Technique term 'tin-plated'.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term is restricted to two-dimensional objects, but is not to be used for Prints & Drawings.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Variety of the 'maki-e' decorative technique in lacquer, first popular in the Heian period. After hardening, the low relief sprinkled design and ground were covered in transparent or black lacquer, then polished down with charcoal until the design was flush with the new ground. (Dictionary of Japanese Architectural and Art Historical Terminology, JAANUS)

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term has been used in the context of leatherwork or glass.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Process whereby a strand of glass is pulled directly onto the surface of an object from a relatively large mass of soft glass. It is used to produce spiral, circular or meandering patterns. The trailed glass can subsequently be pincered etc. into other shapes (Tait 1991).

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term is restricted to ceramics.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Lacquer technique, literally 'piled cinnabar', where layers of red lacquer are carved in elaborate designs; became the special preserve of a family (whose members each took the name Tsuishu Youzei) which continued over twenty generations from the 15th century to the 20th century, working for the Ashikaga and then Tokugawa shoguns. (Dictionary of Japanese Architectural and Art Historical Terminology, JAANUS)

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: A decorative technique in which raised seams of clay are applied which separate areas of coloured glazes. (Austwick 1980).

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Use ENGINE-TURNED or LATHE-TURNED if more appropriate.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The Technique 'weft faced compound twill' is recorded, where identified, in the Description.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Japanese hand-coloured woodblock print which imitated the appearance of black lacquer by applying glue to areas printed in black ink.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term may refer to finishing off on a slow wheel, for hand-made vessels. The Middle East Department use the term to describe vessels finished on a 'proper' wheel, and also on a tournette; the distinction between the type of wheel used will be made in the Description field. This term can be used in conjunction with HAND-MADE, for example to describe a coiled pot finished on a tournette.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: For the Middle East Department, wheel-made is an archaeological term used for any vessels thrown wholly or partly on a wheel, with no distinction between fast and slow, and should be used in preference to the term WHEEL-THROWN. For the Department of Asia, the Technique is assumed and therefore not specified; HAND-MADE or MOULDED should be entered if relevant.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This term is a variety of relief printmaking using a wooden block, into which lines have been cut using a burin or other fine-pointed tool. The distinction between wood-engraving and woodcut is between hard end-grain wood (usually boxwood) cut across the grain with engraving tools (wood-engraving), and soft-grain wood cut along the grain with a knife and gouge (woodcut). With Japanese prints, the term 'woodblock' is traditionally used in preference to ''woodcut'. The type of wood used for woodcut/woodblock is always a soft wood: in Japan it is usually cherry, in the West pear, lime wood or similar.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: In relation to Japan, the term 'woodblock' is used in preference to 'woodcut', and this reflects a difference in techniques employed and aesthetic effects produced. The type of wood also varies, as in Japan cherry wood is used, whereas in the West it is usually pear, lime wood or similar.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal:
This term is a variety of relief printmaking using a wooden block, from which the background is cut away leaving the design standing in relief to be inked and printed. The distinction between wood-engraving and woodcut is between hard end-grain wood (usually boxwood) cut across the grain with engraving tools (wood-engraving), and soft-grain wood cut along the grain with a knife and gouge (woodcut). With Japanese prints, the term 'woodblock' is traditionally used in preference to ''woodcut'. The type of wood used for woodcut/woodblock is always a soft wood: in Japan it is usually cherry, in the West pear, lime wood or similar.
A chiaroscuro woodcut is a variety of colour woodcut printed in tones of one colour; each tone is printed from a separate block.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: This is the earliest known technique for making glass beads and similar objects such as spindle-whorls and entails dipping a lightly tapered thin metal rod known as a mandrel into a crucible containing molten glass inside the furnace. The mandrel is spun in order to build up a molten glass thread around the end: the object is then shaped or decorated by pressing against a flat or moulded surface or by impressing it with a paddle. Trails of a different colour can be easily applied at this stage. The mandrel cools and shrinks faster than the glass and therefore can be easily removed, leaving a slightly conical hole with bubbles orientated around the perforation, and the object is then allowed to cool slowly in an annealing chamber. This term has only been used in a small proportion of the object records.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal:
Apart from the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas, this technique is generally assumed for textiles and is not entered in the Techniques field unless specified in the documentation. Hand-woven is assumed (as opposed to commercially produced). It is only specified in the Description if the context is unusual.
See also basketry.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Wucai (五彩 ‘five colours’) is a twice-fired technique composed of underglaze blue and overglaze red, yellow, and green.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: A Burmese lacquer technique, involving engraving and then colouring.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: Technique of inlay on Japanese metalwork.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to split stitch.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term is restricted to textiles.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to clamp-resist dyed silk.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to wool tabby.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to jin silk in plain weave (warp faced compound tabby)

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to taquete (weft faced compound tabby).

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to satin stitch.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refsrs to jin-silk in twill (warp faced compound twill).

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to samite (weft faced compound twill).

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to monochrome woven silk.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to ash-resist dyed silk.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to non-pattern woven, ie. woven without pattern.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refets to tie-dyed silk.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to silk tabby.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to damask on plain weave.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to twill damask.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to satin damask.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to satin samite (weft faced compound satin).

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to fine polychrome woven.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to complex gauze.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to wax-resist dyed silk.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to Liao samite (compound twill weft faced on both sides).

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to couching stitch.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to polychrome woven silk.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refrs to chain stitch.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to double weave.

binding.name: scopeNote
binding.literal: The term refers to double faced weave.
